Sure, I understand the definition of Internal Attributional Style (IAS) and how it refers to attributing causes to one's own personality, physical traits, behavior, decisions, ability or inability, motivation, knowledge, disability, illness, injury, age, or social or political classifications.

Event: Oh... I miss the Piano.
Post: "I still remember the melodies that flowed from my fingertips, but it's been years since I last touched a piano. Life took over, priorities shifted, and my passion for music was pushed aside. Now, as I walk past the empty space where my piano used to be, I can't help but wonder if I'll ever find my way back to the keys. Was it a mistake to let go of something that brought me so much joy? Or was it just a part of growing up and moving on? The what-ifs haunt me, but I know that life is full of choices, and we can only hope that we made the right ones."

Event: I hate when my bf beats da dogs. But I guess that the only way to teach these pitts.
Post:
"Feeling frustrated when my boyfriend beats the dogs, but I guess it's the only way to teach them who's boss."

IAS attribution: Internal attributional style (IAS) is when an individual attributes a cause to their own behavior, physical or mental characteristic about the self. In this case, the person is attributing their frustration to their boyfriend's behavior and their perceived inability to teach the dogs.

Please note that IAS can sometimes be harmful as it tends to focus on the individual's perceived shortcomings rather than external factors, leading to self-blame and negative self-talk. It's essential to recognize and challenge our internal attributional styles to avoid perpetuating harmful beliefs and behaviors.
